text:
```>>> def gabe():
...     my_list = ['Keshav is cool', 'Paul is cool', 'Doug is cool']
...     for cool in my_list:
...         yield cool
...
>>> generator = gabe()
>>> generator.__next__()
'Keshav is cool'
>>> generator.__next__()
'Paul is cool'
>>> generator.__next__()
'Doug is cool'
>>> generator.__next__()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
StopIteration```
note that it is very rare to actually call `__next__()` and thus receive that error.
mostly you would access generators in a for loop

attachments.title: Introduction to Python Generators
attachments.text: Generators are a very fascinating concept in python; generators have a wide range of applications from simple lazy evaluation to mind-blowing advanced concurrent execution of tasks (see David Beazley). Before we dive into the fascinating world of... | intermediate pythonista | Problem solver by birth. Software engineer and Computer scientist by training.
